user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_ModuleGetInfo_Impl:
```c
int32 OS_ModuleGetInfo_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token, OS_module_prop_t *module_prop)
{
    /*
     * Limiting strictly to POSIX-defined API means there is no defined
     * method to get information about a module contents.
     *
     * The "dlinfo()" function might return some interesting information
     * but this is actually a non-posix extension / platform-defined API.
     *
     * This returns success - although there is no information to add here,
     * the parent/shared layer information is still valid.
     */
    return OS_SUCCESS;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_ModuleGetInfo_Impl:
#define OS_SUCCESS (0)
...
typedef struct OS_object_token OS_object_token_t
...
typedef struct
{
    cpuaddr             entry_point;
    cpuaddr             host_module_id;
    char                filename[OS_MAX_PATH_LEN];
    char                name[OS_MAX_API_NAME];
    OS_module_address_t addr;
} OS_module_prop_t
...
typedef int32_t   int32
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: I found no uses of the standard string-handling functions listed by MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 (memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, strspn, etc.) in the provided code. The implementation of OS_ModuleGetInfo_Impl simply returns OS_SUCCESS and performs no operations on the module_prop or token parameters. The related type definitions only declare fixed-size char arrays (filename, name) but contain no code that reads from or writes to those arrays. There is no pointer arithmetic, no calls to functions that might copy or examine those arrays, and no other code fragments that could produce out-of-bounds accesses within the supplied snippet. Therefore there are no suspicious fragments to investigate for Rule 21.17 in the provided code. (Note: potential violations could occur in other parts of the code that actually populate or manipulate OS_module_prop_t fields, but those parts were not included and thus are outside the scope of this review.)
